questions.prompt: A nonlinear resistor is called voltage-controlled if:
options: A) Its v-i curve passes through the origin
B) For every voltage v, there is exactly one current i (i-hat(v) is single-valued)
C) For every current i, there is exactly one voltage v
D) It has a linear v-i relationship
questions.correctAnswer: B) For every voltage v, there is exactly one current i (i-hat(v) is single-valued)
questions.explanation: Voltage-controlled means the characteristic can be written as i = i-hat(v) where i-hat is single-valued. Every vertical line (constant v) intersects the curve at most once.

questions.prompt: The tunnel diode has an N-shaped v-i characteristic. In the negative resistance region, a single voltage value corresponds to:
options: B) No current (the region is forbidden)
questions.explanation: In the N-shaped curve's NDR region, a vertical line at a given voltage crosses the curve at three points (one on each rising branch and one on the falling branch), giving three current values.

questions.prompt: Because the tunnel diode's i-hat(v) is not single-valued, the tunnel diode is classified as:
questions.explanation: The N-shaped curve fails the vertical line test (not voltage-controlled) but passes the horizontal line test (every horizontal line crosses at most once), so it is current-controlled.

questions.prompt: The glow tube has an S-shaped v-i characteristic. It is classified as:
questions.explanation: The S-shaped curve passes the vertical line test (each voltage gives one current) but fails the horizontal line test (some currents give multiple voltages). So it is voltage-controlled but not current-controlled.
Bilateral (symmetric) means the characteristic is unchanged under 180-degree rotation about the origin: replacing (v, i) with (-v, -i) gives the same curve.

questions.prompt: Which of the following is NOT bilateral?
options: A) A linear resistor v = Ri
B) A cubic resistor i = av^3
C) A PN-junction diode i = Is(e^(v/VT) - 1)
D) A resistor with i = v + v^3
questions.correctAnswer: C) A PN-junction diode i = Is(e^(v/VT) - 1)
questions.explanation: The PN-junction diode's exponential characteristic is not symmetric about the origin: the forward and reverse regions behave completely differently. All the other options satisfy f(-v) = -f(v).

questions.prompt: A sinusoidal voltage v = V0*sin(wt) is applied to a nonlinear resistor with i = av + bv^2. The output current contains:
options: A) Only the fundamental frequency w
B) DC, fundamental w, and second harmonic 2w
D) Fundamental w and third harmonic 3w
questions.correctAnswer: B) DC, fundamental w, and second harmonic 2w
questions.explanation: The linear term gives a component at w. The quadratic term gives sin^2(wt) = (1 - cos(2wt))/2, producing a DC component and a second harmonic at 2w.

questions.prompt: For a bilateral nonlinear resistor excited by a sinusoid, the output contains:
options: B) Only even harmonics plus DC
C) Only odd harmonics (no even harmonics, no DC)
questions.correctAnswer: C) Only odd harmonics (no even harmonics, no DC)
questions.explanation: A bilateral resistor has an odd-symmetric characteristic (only odd powers in its Taylor expansion). Odd powers of sin(wt) produce only odd harmonics. Even harmonics and DC require even-powered nonlinearities.

The exponential i = Is(e^(v/VT) - 1) is strictly monotonic. For every v there is exactly one i (voltage-controlled), and for every i > -Is there is exactly one v (current-controlled). It satisfies both tests.

questions.prompt: The negative differential resistance region of the tunnel diode is exploited in:
options: B) Oscillators and high-speed switching circuits
questions.correctAnswer: B) Oscillators and high-speed switching circuits
questions.explanation: The negative resistance region can supply energy to an external circuit under the right biasing conditions, enabling oscillation and very fast switching. This is the primary application of tunnel diodes.
